text: Specifically, a garbage scow. We see it from ON HIGH, chugging down the placid but migh Mississippi. Head credits play over COVERAGE of the garbage scow. No s except for an incongruously heroic score. The COVERAGE is a little rough, coarse-grained; along wit the overbearing score it almost suggests an industrial fi rather than a feature. One piece of sound -- the toot of the boat's horn -- is  obviously library. And not a new library either. The garbage scow passes under a bridge spanning the broad sluggish waters, and proceeds on to its landfill, a steam river island. Disturbed gulls and other scavenger birds r from where they were picking through trash. Their squawks like the boat horn, are not quite believable as SYNC. The head credits end as the anthemic music resolves.

lies on the weather-grayed and -roughened planking of a f porch. The porch is half-shaded from the noonday sun. It quiet except for the chirr of heat bugs, close by, and, v distant, many voices in chorus, engaged in divine worship a Baptist church sufficiently far away that vagaries of b fan them in and out of audibility. We once again hear the toot of the scow's horn, distant n and played as real, not slapdash effect. At this, the dog lifts his nose to catch the breeze, sniffs, and then, whi lowers his head to the floor and covers his snout with hi forepaws. He huffs briefly and goes to sleep. We DRIFT UP to show that the dog is sleeping before the

Your source for worms, lures, etcetera, etcetera... We TRAVEL OVER TO REVEAL that the modest one-story struct houses two establishments; its other front door leads to SAUCIER MUNICIPAL BUILDING. A campaign sign in the window on the municipal side shows black man of late middle-age beaming and giving the viewe thumbs-up: RE-ELECT WAYNE WYNER SHERIFF/He Is Too Old to Go to Work.
We hear snoring on top of a low, steady hissing sound. We are DRIFTING toward the door of the lock-up, which sta open. The small cell is empty, its bed neatly made.

We are ARCING slowly around a jailer's key on a ring that hangs from a nail. The OFFSCREEN snoring and whirring  continues. The TRACK'S SHIFTING ANGLE now makes the light catch a sp web spun between the key and the wall.

We DRIFT across the face of the radio. The peaceful stead hissing jumps in louder at the CUT: it is uninterrupted: transmissionless, crimeless, misdemeanorless idle radio h The snoring is also louder here. As we TRAVEL OFF the rad we are COMING ONTO a pair of feet propped up on the deskt They belong to SHERIFF WYNER, tipped back in his chair,  fingers laced on his chest, head lolling forward. As the MOVING CAMERA FINALLY ENDS on him, there is the ri of a telephone -- muffled, not present. It nevertheless rouses the sheriff who almost strangles o snore as he awakes, and then rocks forward to pick up his phone.
Sheriff Wyner...
The muffled ringing continues; the sheriff looks, puzzled at the phone. Now the ringing stops and we hear a muffled voice next door:
Worms.

The sheriff replaces the phone, leans back again, adjusts his hat, and is about to go back to sleep when we hear th front door open. The sheriff looks and reacts with genuine, if momentary,  fear. He manages to compose himself and give the intruder a smi
Afternoon, Miz Munson.
Entering is an elderly black woman in a floral print dres and fruited bonnet.
Afternoon, Sheriff. You know the  Funthes boy?
...Mackatee Funthes?
No no, WeeMack! Mackatee's eldest!
Oh yeah, believe I do.
Well, he's a good boy but he done  gone down to the Costco in Pascagoula  and got hisself a blastah -- and he  been playin' that music!
Wyner is not sure where this is going:
Uh-huh...
Loud!
Well--
"Left my wallet in El Segundo!"
He--
Songs like that!
Uh-huh...
Hippity-hop music!
I could--
You know they call it hippity-hop  music, but it don't make me wanna go  hippity-hop!
No ma'am--
And Othar don't like that music  neither!
Sheriff Wyner now displays an exaggerated solicitousness:
It's been disturbin' Othar then, has  it?
How could it help but do! That kind  of music! You know what they call  colored folks in them songs? Have  you got any idea?
I don't think I--
NIGGAZ! I don't wanna say the word.  I won't say it twice, I'll tell you  that. I say it one time.
Yes ma'am.
In the course a swearin' out my  complaint.
Yes'm--
NIGGAZ! Two thousand years after  Jesus! Thirty years after Martin  Luther King! The age of Montel! Sweet  lord a-mercy, izzat where we at?
Mm-mm--
WeeMack down to Pascagoula buyin' a  big thumpy stereo player?! So he can  listen to that word in the house  next to mine? Sheriff, you gotta  help that boy!
Help him?
You gotta take an innarest! EXTEND  that helpin' hand!
(dubious) Well, we're here to help...
Well God bless ya. Don't wanna be  tried and found wantin'.
No ma'am.
Many many tunkalow parzen, Sheriff  Wyner. Many many tunkalow parzen!
Many what ma'am?
You have been tried and found wanting.  Don't want that writin' on the wall!
No ma'am--
Feast a Balthazar!
Mm-hm.
John The Apostle said: Behold there  is a stranger in our midst, come to  destroy us!
Yes ma'am.
Mrs. Munson closes the door behind her. She wags a paper and mutters:
He's a good man. Just needs  instruction. Dog, you in peoples'  way.
The dog stirs with a whine and ambles off.

With a neatly tended garden. It is the last house on a st of other similarly modest but well maintained homes; beyo it the street disappears down a bluff. The empty space be suggests a wide river, and indeed we can see the top of a anchored, gaudily painted paddle-boat poking over the ris The paddle-boat is apparently anchored at the near bank o the river. Mrs. Munson is entering by the gate. She stops in the gar and stoops to pull a tiny weed marring the otherwise perf row of flowers.
Mrs. Munson lets herself in. A cat lopes up to her, the b around its neck tinkling, and leans mewing into her leg.
You need somethin' to eat, Angel?
Mrs. Munson hand-cranks a can opener around a tin of cat  food.
Mm... gizzards...

The cat paces back and forth between her legs, leaning in them and purring, responding to the snap of tin as the co comes off the can. The can contains cubed processed gizzard in a gelatinous  medium like the stuff that clings to gefilte fish.

Above the fireplace is an oil portrait of a serious-looki black man of late middle-age with a neatly groomed mustac starting to gray. A couple of candles sit on the mantel b the portrait, giving it the semblance of a shrine. Mrs. Munson enters and lights the candles.
Othar, I went'n complained about  WeeMack, I hope it'll do some good.  That boy hangin' by a thread! Over  the pit! Fiery pit! "I Left My Wallet  in El Segundo"!
She shakes out the match and sits in a rocker and takes u her knitting. As she sits she gives an audible groan.

...Sixty-seven years of life, forty- six years of marriage, you mean to  tell me you never one time suffered  from piles? It's the human condition,  most humans anyway. Like that ball  player said: world's got two kinds  of folks -- them that's got piles  and them that's gonna get 'em. But  you was always healthy as an ox...
There is the distant moan of a riverboat horn.

...Passed on before you got piles.  Mmmmhmm. Thank the Lord you wasn't  sick. You don't wanna sicken 'n die.  No, you wanna pass nice 'n peaceful...  go to sleep one night, wake up in  the glory land... woof...

A gust of wind hums under the eaves; the candles below th portrait flicker. As Mrs. Munson looks around the room,  vaguely towards the ceiling, sensing a negative aura, the cat arches its back and hisses. At this moment the doorbell rings.
...Well who's that now, Pickles?
She grunts as she hoists herself out of the chair.
She opens the door-- A draft--
The candles below the portrait of Othar go out, sending u thin wisps of smoke.

The cat shrieks and bolts out the door, past the man on t stoop: GOLDTHWAIT HIGGINSON DORR, III. He is a middle-aged Southern gentleman wearing a panama h and a cape over a cream-colored suit. He has dark circles under his eyes. The smile he attempts, mournful yet court is wiped away by:
PICKLES!
Ma'am?
Go get 'im!
I do beg your pardon?
Go get Pickles, I didn't let 'im  out!
(tasting the name) Pickles...
Dorr walks down the stoop followed by the old lady.
Oh, he's up the tree again. Your  gonna have to shimmy on up.
I am so terribly sorry, madam. But  won't the feline eventually tire of  his lonely perch and, pining for his  master's affection, return on his  own initiative?
Huh? No, he won't come down less you  fetch him. He'd set there til Gabriel  blows his horn if someone didn't  shimmy up. Up with you now!

Well then couldn't we perhaps offer  him kitty treats and enticements, or  if not foodstuffs perhaps squeaky  little toys of the kind formerly  manufactured in Hong Kong but now  produced in the other so-called  "Little Tigers"...
His fingers form the quotes.
...of the Pacific Rim? The point  bein', do we have to actually ascend  the tree--
Look, I don't want no doubletalk. If  you ain't gonna fetch him down I  guess I gotta call the po-lice...
Police...
His face darkens.
They ain't gonna be happy. Every  time they come fetch him down they  swear they won't do it no more...
Dorr casts his hat aside and starts awkwardly climbing th tree. He gasps as he climbs:
No need to call the authorities. I  did this often as a youth -- why, I  was a positive lemur... Here, kitty...
The cat backs away down a branch, arching its back and  hissing.
Don't upset him, now!
Dorr, on his stomach, inches after the cat, grunting:
I wouldn't dream of it... harmless  little felix domesticus... Come to  G.H...
The branch breaks, hinging down to slam Dorr face-first i the trunk, from where he drops the rest of the way to the ground.

Othar's portrait, upside-down, seems to be looking bemuse down on us. An OBJECTIVE ANGLE shows Dorr lying on the couch, a damp  washcloth on his forehead, eyes rolled back to look at th picture. Mrs. Munson is entering with a cup of tea. Dorr swings hi feet out to sit up and accept the tea.
I thank you, madam, for your act of  kindness.
Well you let him out.
I certainly did and I do apologize  no end. Allow me to present myself,  uh, formally: Goldthwait Higginson  Dorr, Ph.D.
What, like Elmer?
Beg your pardon, ma'am?
Fudd?

No no, Ph.D. is a mark of academic  attainment. It is a degree of higher  learning bestowed, in my case, in  recognition of my mastery of the  antique languages of Latin and Greek.  I also hold a number of other advanced  degrees including the baccalaureate  from a school in Paris, France, called  the Sorbonne.
Munson chuckles.
Sore bone, well I guess that's  appropriate. You ever study at Bob  Jones University?
I have not had that privilege.
It's a bible school, only the finest  in the country. I send them five  dollars every month.
That's very gener--
I'm on their mailing list. I'm an  Angel.
Indeed.
They list my name in the newsletter,  every issue. I got the literature  here, you wanna examine it.
Perhaps when my head has recovered  from its... buffeting. Mrs. Munson,  are you at all curious as to why I  darkened your door, as the expression  has it, on this lovely camelia-scented  morn?
I was wondering, til you let Pickles  out. Then in all the excitement--
I quite understand. The fact is that  I saw the sign on your window  advertising a room to let, and it is  the only such sign among the houses  of this charming, charming street.
Yeah, I got a room. I'm lookin' for  a quiet tenant. Fifteen dollars a  week
I quite understand. Madam, you are  addressing a man who is quiet -- and  yet not quiet, if I may offer a  riddle...
He sets down the teacup and rises.
...Perhaps you can show me the room,  Mrs. Munson, and allow me to explain.
Well you can see the room, but I  don't like double-talk.
Mrs. Munson precedes him...
...up the stairs.

You see, madam, I am currently on  sabbatical from the institution where  I teach -- the University of  Mississippi at Hattiesburg. I am  taking a year off to indulge my  passion -- I don't believe that is  too strong a word -- for the music  of the Renaissance. I perform in --  and have the honor of directing -- a  period instrument ensemble that  performs at Renaissance fairs and  other cultural fora...
They enter a small bedroom. There is a small bed on a bra frame, a chair, a wash basin, and cheerful yellow chintz  drapes on the window. Dorr appreciatively takes it in.
...thoo-out central and southern  Mississippi. We perform on the  instruments for which the music was  originally composed, in the belief  that... that... Why, this is lovely...
Wait a minute. You got some kind of  band?
Dorr once again wiggles quotes with his fingers:

The word "band" would be, in this  context, something of an anachronism.  Though we do play together -- hence  the word "ensemble" -- the nature of  the music is such that one would  hesitate to apply the epithet "band"  with its connotations of jangling  rhythm and ear-popping amplification.
So you don't play hippity-hop, "I  Left My Wallet in El Segundo," songs  with the titles spelt all funny?

Madam, I shudder. I quake. The  revulsion I feel for modern popular  music, and all other manifestations  of contemporary decay, is, I have no  doubt, the equal of y'own. Why, we  play music that was composed to the  greater glory of God. Devotional  music. Church music.
Gospel music?
Well-inspired by the gospels,  certainly. The vintage, of course,  is no more recent than the Rococo.
Rococo, huh? Well, I guess that'd be  okay.
But I certainly don't propose to  inflict our rehearsals on you. May I  enquire -- do you have a root cellar?
Dorr ducks while descending the steep, narrow stair in or to avoid an overhead beam. He is followed by Mrs. Munson.
Yes, yes, yes, this looks promising...
He pulls on a hanging string to light a bare bulb overhea
Little dank, ain't it?
Oh, indeed, but that only improves  the acoustics...
He experimentally claps his hands.

...Marvelous. These earthen walls  are ideal for baffling the higher  registers of the, uh, lute and, uh,  sackbutt. That's why so much music  of the cinquecento was played in  crypts and catacombs. Yes, this will  do nicely...
He dry-washes his hands with enthusiasm, but his tone rem mournful.
...This is perfect. This is more  than perfect. I can scarcely contain  my glee.
You containing it okay.
He starts to peel cash out of a large, well-worn billfold

Allow me to pay you a week in advance.  Allow me to pay you two weeks in  advance. Allow me to pay you a month  in advance. I cannot countenance the  thought of these charming apartments  being tenanted by someone  unappreciative of their special je  ne sais quoi.
That would be a shame.
On the cart is a boombox. It is playing "I Left My Wallet El Segundo." It is being pushed through a casino empty of customers. As the cart stops and a wastebasket is emptied into it:
You gotta peel this shit out sticks  to the bottom.
shows two youngish black men in the khaki uniforms of  custodians. Emptying the wastebasket is WEEMACK-MACKATEE  FUNTHES. He is instructing GAWAIN MACSAM.

...You wouldn't believe this shit,  sometimes even out here on the casino  floor you gonna find sanitary napkin  shit stuck there, Tucks, I don't  know what the fuck people do while  they're gambling here man.
I ain't peelin' funky shit with my  human hands, man. That's a  prescription for disease and viruses  and shit, attackin' y'insides.

As they roll on we see more of the gambling floor, which on something less than the scale of a Las Vegas casino. T floor is not yet open and dealers stack and count chips a the tables, pit bosses with clipboards looking over their shoulders. Other dealers strap on visors and sleeve garte preparing to work.
You gotta do it. Mr. Gudge checks  everything. Man is a motherfuck.  Shit -- looka this.
After a furtive look around he plucks a chip from the nex wastebasket and slips it in his pocket.
...You keep an eye out, man. I found  a hundred-dollar chip once.
Fuck that, man. I ain't pawin' through  used Tucks for a fi' dollar chip.
I said it was a hundred.
Man, your guts gonna turn to soup'n  leak outcha fuckin' asshole.
The cart jitters loudly on the dimpled plastic floor.
This tunnel leads back onto land. To  the office for all the people work  for Mannex. Mannex Corporation. Owns  the Lady Luck 'n three other boats...
The two men are entering a windowless fluorescent-lit off area. A row of wooden office doors and one heavy steel do
...This is where they think on their  corporate shit, Gudge and them.
He stops to empty a wastebasket.
...The lights is ugly but it ain't  as many Tucks.
He bangs on the steel door:
...YO, motherfuck! Lemme in!
What's the password?
Kiss my ass.
We hear a deep chuckle and the door, steel reinforced, sw open.
The two men enter, WeeMack nodding at the security man  (ELRON).
This is where they count the dough.  You try to take any of it Elron there  shoot your ass.
Again the security man chuckles. WeeMack picks up some fa food wrappers.
...This place is a fuckin' pigsty.  You a pig, man, nothin' but a squeaky  ol' motherfuckin' pig...
Elron chuckles. He is an enormously fat man; his chuckles come from deep, deep in his chest.
...You got fuckin' Kocoa Krispies in  ya uniform man, still got breakfast  there and you eatin' motherfuckin'  lunch.
Elron uses one hand to swipe crumbs off his uniform shirt chuckling.
...You a disgrace before motherfuckin'  God...
Elron chuckles.
...You a motherfuck-- oh, hello Mr.  Gudge, how we be this mornin'?
A man in a buttoned white shirt nods at him.
Funthes. How's the new man?
He is a cleaning motherfucker, man!
Is that a fact.

It is a ruin of a field; charred trees point bare and gna limbs toward a gray sky; smoke drifts across the desolate waste. Something is bounding towards us from the deep background We BOOM DOWN as it approaches: a bulldog, running avidly  toward us on its stumpy little legs. An OFFSCREEN male voice (CLARK PANCAKE):
One, Mountain!
There is an explosion that showers dirt in front of the d and makes it veer. Something strapped around the dog's ne bounces as he runs.
...Scrub two! Scrub three! Four,  Mountain!

Another explosion makes the dog veer back so that it once again bears on us. The thing that has been bouncing aroun its neck flies off. Our CONTINUING BOOM DOWN has brought us to ground level j as the dog arrives in front of us to feed at a dog food b in the foreground. The yellow plastic bowl has a K-Ration logo facing us. We hear another OFFSCREEN voice (DIRECTOR):
Cut, goddamnit. His canteen fell  off.
The Director's feet enter in the foreground. He hooks the dogs belly with one foot and hoists it roughly away from bowl. We
The DIRECTOR. He scowls down at the animal.
...Props!

A man in a Hemingway field-jacket with multiple pockets, also a loaded utility belt, trots up toward him, his belt jangling as he runs. This is CLARK PANCAKE. Pancake is a florid beer-bellied man in his late fifties. has a full blond-grey Grizzly Adams beard and wears multi pocketed shorts that form an ensemble with his Hemingway  jacket. The director is angry.
...The goddamn thing's canteen fell  off. It would have been a good take.
Pancake is unperturbed.
Okay. Okay. We're prepared for that...
He hits a button on the radio on his belt and talks into headset:
... Mountain, bring Otto with the  apparatus.

He strains at his lead, muscling forward as quickly as hi minder and his own stumpy little legs will allow. He peers through the two goggly eyeholes of an antique le gas mask, its pignose breathing apparatus covering his ow snout. His phlegmy breathing is amplified by the device. We TILT UP the lead to show his minder, MOUNTAIN GIRL. Sh is a solid woman in her late forties with freckles beginn to merge into age spots. Her long straw-colored hair is  tightly braided into Heidi pigtails bound with red ribbon Otherwise her dress is unadorned. The director squints at the dog.
What the hell is this?
Pancake's manner is professorial:

World War I vintage gas mask. It's  authentic. Strapped on, of course,  so it can't fall off. The animal is  free to be as active as he wants,  doesn't inhibit his movement, and I  think it really sells the whole  doughboy thing--
It looks like a fucking joke.
Pancake stares at the director for a moment and, though n doing anything, makes a sound of concentrated effort:
...Nnnnrnff!
The director squints at him:
What?
Pancake comes out of his trance, or whatever it was:
No, nothing, uh... you're absolutely  right, the gas mask is a whimsical  concept--
How the hell does it eat when it  gets to the Kennel Rations?
The dog looks up from person to person as each speaks,  twisting its neck to peer through the eyeholes. Its breat is growing louder.
Well, you're absolutely right-
Don't let the client see this.
Of course not, that would be  inappropriate--
Or the Humane fucker.
No no--
The dog gets down on its knees, slowly, like a camel,  breathing ever more loudly.
They'll shut the fucking spot down,  Pancake. Put the goddamn canteen  back on. That says he's a soldier.  Dented tin canteen. Just tie the  damn thing to his collar.
The dog flops over into the mud.
Easiest thing in the world. I just  thought -- but the canteen is much  better. Good concept. Let's go with  that--
What's he doing?
The dog has started to convulse.
Well, he's uh... Just breathe  normally, Otto.
The fucking dog can't breathe.
Oh, he can breathe, that thing is --  just breathe normally, Otto.
The dog's breath is rasping and horrible.
The fucking dog cannot breathe! Get  that fucking thing off him!
Of course. Easiest thing in the world.
He stoops and fiddles at the straps.
...It's on good and tight, I, uh...  Just breathe normally, Otto.
He starts thumping at his pockets.
Get the fucking thing off him!
Don't have my Leatherman. Mountain!  Give me your Leatherman! Chop chop!
Get the fucking thing off him! Chitra,  make sure the Humane fucker doesn't  come over here! Bring him to craft  services!
As he makes to scoop up the dog:
Good idea! Ice water, treats-
Not the dog, you idiot! The Humane  fucker! Distract him!
Right! Of course!
He goes back to work on the mask.
Oh my god, he's bleeding!
No, that's me -- I -- the  Leatherman... here we go.
His hand gouting blood, he finally manages to get the gas mask off. A crowd is starting to gather and gape. The director bark at a grip:
Put up a couple solids here -- I  don't want the client seeing this!
Pancake thumps on the inert dog's chest.
Come on, Otto!
Otto is fucking dead!
Mountain, have electric run me a  stinger! Don't give up on me, Otto!  Mountain, I need two live leads!
More people crowd in to look.
Clark, the gennie's a hundred yards  away!
Goddamnit! Otto's gonna have brain  damage in about ninety seconds! Okay!
He pulls the dog's lips back, exposing its teeth and slob tongue.
...Kiss of life!
He sucks in a deep breath and starts mouth-to-mouthing th beast.

We are looking out from inside a football helmet; we hear the super-present breathing of the helmet's occupant. Jus over the breathing we can hear the muffled shouting of a  snap count. We are in a crouch position looking downfield. At the cal of "Hike!" we and everyone on the field spring into actio We sprint downfield, the breathing becoming even louder. very big person downfield is sprinting toward us. After several yards, still on the move, we PAN quickly ar to look back for the quarterback. Barely visible among  converging bodies, he is releasing the football toward so else. Easing up on the run we PAN BACK around to look downfield just as the oncoming defender is upon us and -- CRUNCH -- slams into us. A STROBING PAN leaves us looking up at the sky. Our loud breathing has stopped. After a long beat the breathing resumes with a raggedy la inhale. It continues irregularly. Another helmeted player appears above us to peer down into our helmet. He extends hand to help us up.
We are looking back and forth around the circle at our  gathered teammates.
Delta thirty-seven. On four!
All, with a simultaneous hand clap:
Huh!

Lined up opposite us is a snarling defender. Once again, over loud breathing, we can just hear the sho count. At "Hike!" we straighten to meet the defensive lineman lu at us. His mouthpiece clatters against ours and in horrif CLOSE-UP he strains against us, his animal gurgles of eff audible over our own ragged breath. With a primal roar from the defenseman our POV tips back up, BOOMING DOWN to stop with a CRUNCH against the ground staring up. Once again our breathing has stopped. After a beat a foot is planted on our helmet as a looming running back steps on us in his charge downfield. He is  pursued by defenders some of whom leap over us and some o whom by the sound of it step on various body parts.
The same back-and-forth PAN.
Okay, Epsilon twenty-two! You the  man!... Hey! BUTTHEAD!
This brings our wandering attention PANNING back to the  quarterback:
You the man!
A very, very present VOICE (HUDSON):
Me the man?
Huh!
The same breathing and count. On "Hike!" we sprint downfield. The same distant defender sprinting toward us. We hear low but very present a dismayed:
Unh... oh no...

Our breathing is torn by rasping wheezes of effort as we  continue to run. We look back. Every player is looking directly at us. A huge spiralling football coming at us -- too close, too soon -- and--
It bounces off our mouth guard and flies up.
...shit...
We are looking forward just as

We are hit by the defender. We once again land face-up. Very steeply FORESHORTENED, right over us, we see the def juggling the live ball. With a moan, our own hand reaches weakly up towards the b and the high, distant defender. He finally gathers in the ball and securely tucks it, and starts back upfield. We climb wearily to our feet. We look back upfield just i time to see the defender start an elaborate victory dance the end zone. He pauses for a moment to point a gloved ha directly at us, then resumes his strut. Shouting from the sidelines brings our PANNING attention  over. The coach, face twisted with fury, is shouting at us and  using his clipboard to wave us off the field. We trot toward the sidelines. All of our teammates stare at us - some in shock, some in anger, some in pity. At the sideline bench our POV swings round as we seat our A hand reaches up to the mouth guard to pull off the helm and we
Our first OBJECTIVE SHOT as the player (HUDSON) finishes  pulling off his helmet. He is a big blond boy. His entire body, including his face, is solidly built. An offscreen Voice:
Hudson!
The boy, Hudson, turns to look, and we cut to one last
The COACH is striding up, swinging his clipboard at the  camera: with a loud CRUNCH! it brings on:

It is a typical sunbaked concrete strip mall with a Seven Eleven, a launderette, and a Hi-Ho Donut. The Hi-Ho Donut sign shows a pink donut with sprinkles and says in much  smaller lettering: And Croissants. A beat-up Impala pulls into the lot, pulsing hip-hop musi After a long rumbling idle the ignition is killed. Both f doors open. Two BLACK KIDS get out and look around with a manner that is if anything too casual.

There is faint muzak and loud air-conditioner hum. Glass  cases display donuts identified as GLAZED, JELLY, and FAN Fancies ooze yellow goo. The jelly on the jelly donuts is developing a crust of age. The glazed also look moth-eate One customer, a disheveled older man, sits at one of the  little formica tables staring into a coffee cup. Next to coffee is a brown paper bag from which a straw protrudes. Behind the counter is a middle-aged VIETNAMESE WOMAN in a neat white blouse. The two youths enter pulling out enormous handguns from  underneath their windbreakers.
All right Dragon Lady, give us all  the fuckin' money!
The woman stares blankly.
We want that donut money!
Yao gin nyap!

A man appears from the kitchen in back. He is a middle-ag Vietnamese gentleman in a crisply pressed khaki leisure s An ascot is knotted at his neck. He wears aviator eyeglas In his mouth smolders a half-burned-down filterless cigar This, we shall learn later, is THE GENERAL.
Okay papa-san, we want that donut  money.
And we ain't fuckin' around, Mr. Hi- Ho.
Hi-Ho.
The two youths look at her briefly. Nothing else is  forthcoming. The drunk looks up from his paper bag.

She certainly does.
Therefore -- to draw the unavoidable  conclusion -- someone shall have to  reenter the tunnel to reset that  charge.

Pancake, hunched over, scurries along the tunnel. He reac the remnants of a large rock, where the tunnel grows smal He drops to crawl position and elbows his way forward,  toolbelt clanking along. We are getting closer and closer to a muffled but thuddin bassy "I Left My Wallet in El Segundo."
The music loudly present at the cut. Gawain takes a handh blowdryer out of his satchel and flips it on, directing i at the fresh paint on the wall whose repairs are now  invisible.

Music once again muffled. Pancake has reached a little LE displaying timer with leads trailing off of it. He grabs it, puts on his reading glasses, squints. The display shows: TIME REMAINING: 00:12. The colons in the display rhythmically blink, but the num does not advance. For some reason, stuck.
Huh.
He reaches to his tool belt, pulls out his Leatherman.
Mrs. Munson is setting places at a large table. There are about a dozen place settings.
Pancake now has a mini-mag light clenched between his tee aimed down at the timer. He opens the phillips head on hi Leatherman but abruptly stops and stares off into space.
Nnnnrungh...
He is squinting with pain. The muffled hip-hop song is beginning to recede.
Gawain is wheeling his garbage cart out the door. The vau is completely empty but looks completely undisturbed. He closes the heavy vault door behind him, leaving quiet.
Quiet here as well, now. Pancake's moan trails off to not He relaxes. The moment, whatever it was, has passed. He looks back down at the unit, flicks it with his finger and it emits a soft beep.
...Huh?

He squints at the back of the unit. As it beeps again, he turns the unit over to look at its  face. The readout now says: 00:10. As he watches, peering down through the bottom of his gla it continues to advance with a beep as each second slips 9... 8...
...What the--

His eyes widen and he frantically shakes the unit. It  continues beeping. He briefly and sloppily tries to fit t phillips head into one of the four screws on the back of unit but immediately gives up and starts a panicked wrigg back up the tunnel, whimpering.
Gawain is wheeling his garbage cart past Elron.
Mrs. Munson is placing the last piece of silverware, just so.
Pancake is in full panicked awkward flight as--
--BOOM! We CUT TO the cellar and Pancake is shot out the  tunnel like a human cannonball, trailing a comet-tail of  dirt, dust, and debris that wafts what were neatly stacke bills up into the air.

The portrait of Othar jostles back to square. He now look little angry. The cat arches her back, emitting a startled yowl. Mrs. Munson stands, frozen, then looks slowly around, try to assimilate what has just happened.
Gawain and Elron are staring at each other, frozen, also  reacting to what just happened. Finally:
...You just fart?
Heh-heh-heh.

Mrs. Munson is looking at the cellar door. Dust drifts ou from under it. She takes a slow step towards it. Another step. She opens the door. There is no visibility in the cellar due to swirling clay dust. She takes one step down the stairs, waving at the air in  front of her face. Paper money wafts in and out of the dust. We hear Voices:
Perfectly all right. Not a problem.
Well there sure as shit ain't no  tunnel left.

The clearing dust reveals the caped Professor anxiously  dancing from foot to foot, gathering money out of the air As he reaches up to grab a bill that has him facing up in Mrs. Munson's direction, he freezes. His POV reveals her through dissipating dust.
Professor, I'm surprised.
There is a long beat, through which all stare at her.
...Properly speaking, madam, we have  been surprised; you are taken aback.  Though I acknowledge that the sense  you intend is gaining currency through  increasing use.
Further dissipation of the dust reveals how much money th is, settling now to cover the floor of the cellar.
...You have returned from your  devotions betimes.
We hear the ring of the doorbell.
I hadda fix tea. I wanna talk to  you, Professor, don't you be leavin'.  And don't make any more noise! And  you!
She points at the General who, in the excitement, has  neglected to hide his ever-present cigarette.
...I told you, I don't want any  smokin' in here!
She clomps upstairs and shuts the cellar door.

We PULL HER towards the front door, angry and lost in tho Her look softens somewhat as she opens the door. It is a chattering infestation of hens: all of her friend from church push in wearing church dresses and elaborate  hats.
The men are still frozen looking up toward the door. The  muted cackle of church ladies. The men gradually unfreeze.
She saw everything. She saw our  hole...
He turns to Dorr, near tears:
...She saw our hole, Professor!
Dorr rubs his hands anxiously, thinking:
Yes... Yes...
What do we do?
Well, first, my dear boy, we follow  the General's example...
The General remains staring up at the door, frozen but fo the smoke pluming from the cigarette in his mouth.
...and refrain from panic. Secondly,  we cooly, calmly, collectedly think...  think...
The gaze of all the men drifts back up to the cellar door and we look down at them, gazing up.

The chattering ladies are gathered at the table, Mrs. Mun pouring them tea. The cellar door creaks noisily -- one might almost say  gothically -- ajar, and the Professor peers out with an  ingratiating smile.
Hsst... Madam...
The chattering abates and the ladies all look at him. His smile broadens into ghastliness and he crooks a finger to Mrs. Munson.
...Mrs. Munson, if I might have a  word...
You get back down those stairs!
I assure you I shall be--
Hush! Down those stairs! We havin'  tea now! I be down shortly.
He nods meekly and retreats, easing the door creakily shu The ladies look inquisitively at Mrs. Munson as his foots are heard descending the stair.
...He's the tenant.
Mm-hm.
As the Professor rejoins the still staring and silent gro The money has been picked up and is once again in stacks  upon the table.
She shall be down shortly...
Explaining, he indicates upstairs with a jerk of the head
...Tea. Dainties.

The men nod, murmuring. The cellar door squeaks open. There is the clomp of caref footsteps on the stair. Using only tongue and teeth, the General flips his smokin cigarette inwards into his mouth and gives Mrs. Munson hi usual deadpan look. She halts halfway down the stairs, still wearing an apron and holding a spatula.

I don't know what you boys been up  to but I wasn't born yesterday and I  know mischief when I see it. Now I  want an explanation, but first I  want you boys to get your fannies up  here with y'alls period instruments.  I been tellin' the ladies about your  music and they wanna hear you play.
She turns to head back up the stairs but abruptly stops t turn and give the General a hard look which he innocently returns.
...Hmph.
She turns again and clomps back up the stairs. The General opens his mouth and, again without using his  hands, restores his cigarette to its usual place on his l lip. Lump is fretful:
Professor?
Yes, Lump?
I can't really play the buttsack.
The cellar door opens and the men troop out, G.H. Dorr le and the other men following rather sheepishly behind.

Madame -- or rather, mesdames -- you  will have to accept our apologies  for failing to perform since, as you  see, we are shorthanded. Gawain is  still at work and we could no more  play with one part tacit than a horse  could canter shy one leg.
Mm-hmm.
Hmph.

Perhaps I could offer as a poor but  ready substitute a brief poetic  recital. Though I don't pretend to  great oratorical skills, I will  happily present, with your ladies'  permission, verse from the unquiet  mind of Mr. Ed G'Allan Poe.
Lump, Pancake, and the General sit and awkwardly accept d teacups. The Professor rises, spreads his hand, and pronounces:
..."Ladies, thy beauty is to me Like  those Nicean barks of yore..."
CLOSE-UPS of the various ladies, some sipping tea or slow munching biscuits, but all eyes glued to the declaiming m in the cape.
"That gently, o'er a perfumed sea  The weary, wayworn wanderer bore To  his own native shore... "
Murmuring Voice:
Amen.
A slurp of tea from another quarter. Dorr bears on:
"On desperate seas long wont to roam,  Thy hyacinth hair, thy classic face,  Thy Naiad airs have brought me home  To the glory that was Greece And the  grandeur that was Rome... "
A long silence. Then, scattered:
Mm-mm. Glory hallelujah.
A lady holding a teacup turns to the General:
That was soooome poem.
The General stares at her.
...You know any?

We hear the front door opening and Gawain enters, still  wearing his Lady Luck custodial uniform. He looks. His POV: church ladies with teacups and his comrades seat among them, also holding teacups and scones.
Y'all been celebratin'?.

The bustling and chattering ladies are just finishing lea Mrs. Munson is seeing them off at the door. Evening is  gathering, and we hear the lonely toot of the distant gar scow. The men as well stand by the door and, affecting good che wave off the departing ladies.
Goodbye, ladies. We had such a  pleasant time.
Mrs. Munson closes the door and her manner instantly dark
Now, I wanna know what's goin' on.

Yes indeed, and the thirst for  knowledge is a very commendable thing.  Though in this instance, I believe  when you hear the explanation, you  will laugh riotously, slappin' your  knee and perhaps even wipin' away a  giddy tear, relieved of your former  concern.
Hmph.

You see Lump here is an enthusiastic  collector of Indian arrowheads and,  having found one simply lying on  your cellar floor, a particularly  rare artifact of the Natchez tribe,  he enlisted us in an all-out effort  to sift through the subsoil in search  of others. Well, in doing so, we  apparently hit a motherlode of natural  gas -- I myself became acutely aware  of the smell of "rotten eggs" -- and  it was at just this unfortunate moment  that the General here violated one  of the cardinal rules of this house  and lit himself a cigarette.
The General stiffly bows:
So sorry.
The Professor, nodding, smiling, and dry-washing his hand continues to look at Mrs. Munson, though his story,  apparently, has ended. She returns his ingratiating look with a stare.
...What about all that money?
Dorr's smile fades.
...Ah. The money. The money is...  Mr. Pancake's.
That's right.

He only just re-mortgaged his house  in order to pay for the procedure  that will correct the wandering eye  of his common-law wife, Mountain  Water, who suffers from astygmia and  strabismus and a general curdling of  the vitreous jelly. Mr. Pancake  however is an ardent foe of the  federal reserve and is in fact one  of those eccentrics about whom one  occasionally reads, hoarding his  entire life savings either under the  proverbial mattress or, as in Mr.  Pancake's case, in a Hefty bag that  is his constant companion.
Under her stare, he elaborates:
...Steel Sack.
Don't trust the banks. Never have.
She thinks, decides.
This don't smell right. I'm callin'  Sheriff Wyner.
A chorus of gasps.
Madam -- if you please. Yes! Yes! It  was a lie! A fantastic tale! You  have us! Dead to rights! But please  allow me to tell you the truth -- in  private.
He escorts her to sit beneath the portrait of Othar, sits across from her, and leans confidentially in.
Madam...
He agonizes. The words do not come easy.
...What I am about to reveal to you,  you may find... shocking. Mrs. Munson,  I must tell you that we are not...  what we appear.
Mm-hm.

We are not in fact musicians of the  late Renaissance. Nor of the early  or mid period. We are, in fact...  criminals! Desperate men, madam! We  have tunneled into the nearby offices  of the Lady Luck gambling emporium  and have relieved it of its treasure!
Lord have mercy!

It is true that the Lady Luck is a  den of iniquity, a painted harlot  luring people into sin and exciting  the vice of greed with her false  promise of easy winnings. Oh, her  gains are ill-gotten, yes, but I  offer no excuses -- save one! We men  have each pledged half of our share  of the booty to a charitable  institution -- the General, to a  placement service for Southeast Asian  refugees; Mr. Pancake to the Blue  Ridge Parkway Conservancy; and Lump  to the United Jewish Appeal. As  compensation for use of your house  we had planned to donate a full share  to Bob Jones University, without  burdening you with guilty knowledge  by informing you of same. But you  have wrested the information from  me! Now it is all on the table. Now  you have it, the whole story, the  awful truth.
Stolen money!

Yes, yes, shamefully I admit it,  yes! But find the victim, Mrs. Munson,  I challenge you! Even the casino  itself, that riparian Gomorra, shall  suffer no harm! It has an insurance  company, a financial behemoth that  will cheerfully replenish its depleted  vaults! That is its function! And  the insurance company itself is made  up of tens and tens of thousands of  policy-holders so that -- we have  done the calculations, Mrs. Munson! --  so that at the end of the day, at  the final reckoning, each policy- holder shall have contributed only  one penny -- one single solitary  cent -- to the satisfaction of this  claim.
...Just one penny?

Think of it, Mrs. Munson! One cent  from thousands upon thousands of  people so that Bob Jones University  can continue on its mission! Why, I  have no doubt that, were the policy- holders aware of the existence of  that august institution, why, each  and every one of them would have  volunteered some token amount to the  furtherance of its aims!
Well that's prob'ly true...
The Professor, warming, has resumed dry-washing his hands

Yes madam, sadly, the criminal stain  is upon my soul, but the benefit  shall accrue to any number of worthy  causes. As long, that is, as the  secret stays with us. And I, surely,  shall not be the one to divulge it.
Mrs. Munson nods, musing.
Well... it's hard to see the harm in  it... One penny...
Her gaze drifts around the room, a smile beginning to war her face. The smile freezes, though, as her look catches something. Her POV: Othar, above the mantle, looks down with a  disapproving scowl.
...I'm sorry, Professor.
Dorr is taken aback:
Excuse me, ma'am?
No. It's wrong. Don't you be leadin'  me into temptation.
Madam, I must strenuously protest--
No, it's just plain wrong. Stealin'.  I know your intentions were good,  and I won't call the police if you  give the money back. But I gotta see  that you do it.
Madam--
And all a you gotta go to church  with me next Sunday.
The Professor is incredulous:
And... engage in divine worship?
I made up my mind. You can double- talk all you want, but its church or  the county jail.
But--
She rises.
You think it over. I gotta feed the  cat.
The men all sit around the card table, lit from below by oil lamp. The General is neatly packing the stacks of  banknotes into the sackbutt case.
Motherfuck!
Yes. Unfortunately, Mrs. Munson has  rather complicated the situation--
I know how to discomplicate it! Put  a cap in the old lady's head! Then  everything simple again!
The group lapses into silence, considering. Even Gawain n a moment to digest the horror that he himself has propose The Professor is solemn:

...Not easy to do. Many reasons.  Practical ones: a quiet neighborhood,  a sleepy town. Reasons of moral  repugnance: a harmless woman, a deed  conceived and executed in cold blood.  No, Gawain; would that it were simple!
Well -- fuck, man! What we gonna do,  give the money back and go to church?!
I shudder. I quake.
He turns to the General.
...You sir, are a Buddhist. Is there  not a middle way?
The General grunts as he closes the clasps on the sackbut case full of money:
Must float like a leaf on the river  of life. And kill old lady.
The men murmur.

Well... I suppose you are right. It  is the active nature of the crime,  though, that so horrifies -- the  squeezing of the trigger, the plunging  of the knife. But, think a moment --  look at the other tools we have at  hand.
He looks around.
...We have the cellar. We have masonry  and trowel. Perhaps we could simply...  immure her.
Sure, easiest thing in the world. I  could whip up a little mortar in one  of those snow saucers, lay the bricks,  anchor in some chains, Mountain has  a source for the manacles...

Ahh but gentlemen, we delude  ourselves. Think of the woman's  piteous moans as we lay tier upon  tier of brick. Think of her  lamentations as we fit the last brick  into place, appealing to our better  selves, the higher angels of our  nature, our recollections of our own  sainted mothers... No, I fear that  we lack the sand to commit such an  act. No... no... shortest and most  painless is best. Let us confront  reality. Gawain's gun... the retort  muffled by a pillow... into the  brain... the affair of an instant.  The only question is... who wields  the weapon.
He looks around the table. Silence. No volunteers.
...I believe it is traditional, in  such circumstances, to draw straws.
Well, sure, fair enough.
He takes a broom leaning against the wall, bends back and snaps a handful of its bristles.

...I'm thinking, though, that since  I lost my finger -- I mean, literally  lost it because of that goddamn cat --  maybe I should be excused from this  thing. Hard for me to squeeze a  trigger anyway--
You one whiney motherfucker! I squeeze  your nutsack you keep that up!
Listen, punk--
Gentlemen, no special pleading, no  exceptions. It's in the nature of  the situation that we would all prefer  to be excused.
Pancake grumbles as he counts out five bristles, takes on and snaps it in half, displaying the short straw to the g and then hands the four long and one short to the Profess
Well, okay... it was just a trial  balloon...

With a flap of his cape the professor jumbles the straws encloses them in one hand. Sweaty CLOSE-UPS. Each man stares at the straws. Some  hesitant, some resolute, they draw: First, the General: long straw. His reaction: impassive. Next, Lump: long straw. His reaction: relieved. Next, Pancake. Long straw.
Long straw. You all see it. All your  fuss over nothing, punk.
Two straws left. Gawain stares at them, licks his lips. He reaches for one straw, touches it, hesitates.
...Motherfucker...

He touches the other straw, hesitates. He goes back to the first straw, closes his hand around i closes his eyes, and pulls. He lifts the straw into frame before his squeezed-shut ey raises his eyebrows, and slowly opens fluttering eyelids look: short straw. The Professor, smiling, opens his fist to confirm that he holds the last long one. Gawain moans.

Slowly, slowly, Gawain mounts the cellar stairs. Behind h gathered in a semi-circle and looking up from the foot of the stairs, the other men wait. As he plants one plodding foot in front of the other Gawa raises the gun, slides back its primer to make sure there a round in the chamber, and then slides it shut as he rea the door.

In the foreground Mrs. Munson sits knitting, humming an o temperance tune. In the background the cellar door swings open. Marva Munson doesn't notice; her knitting needles  continue their rhythmic clack. We PULL Gawain, gun at the ready, as he takes slow, cauti steps across the floor. We INTERCUT his POV of the back of the old lady's head, b over her knitting. As Gawain passes the sofa he picks up a cushion and burie in it his hand holding the gun. He looks back up at the old lady. But now, still cautious approaching, he cocks his head, his expression bemused.
nearing the old lady is now different somehow. The perspe is somewhat lower; the humming woman sounds not quite the same; the rocking chair and the room itself are subtly  different.

head_text.subj: WHEN WE CUT BACK TO GAWAIN

text: he is a runty, TEN-YEAR-OLD CHILD walking slowly across t floor; he is cradling not a gun in a pillow but a squirmi little puppy dog. The dog yips; the woman turns to look at us. It is not Mr Munson, but another black woman of about the same age.
What you got there, Gawain?
Why -- nothin', mama.
Nothin' my ass! You got a dog there!
No, Mama!
A filthy noisy little pest of a puppy  dog gonna shit all over the house!
He won't shit in the house, Mama,  I'm gonna train him, I promise, gonna  train him real good--
WHAP! She cuffs him on the side of his head.
I'm gonna train you real good! I  told you don't bring no stray dogs  into this house!
WHAP! Another slap.
...You wait til your Daddy gets home,  he gonna lay into you proper!
The little boy, weeping, throws his arms around his mothe
Please don't hurt me no more! I love  you, Mama!
Daddy gonna kick your ass!
...Bringin' in a filthy dirty dog!
WHAP! Gawain's little brothers and sisters, drawn by the  commotion, have gathered excitedly to watch.
Mama's whuppin' Gawain's ass!
(eagerly) Ain't you gonna use the strap, Mama?
WHAP! WHAP! Gawain is sobbing:
Please don't hurt me, Mama!
Now it is the adult Gawain blubbering. The clack of knitting needles stops and Mrs. Munson turns look.
What you doin'? What you doin' with  my pillow there?
He surreptitiously slides the gun into his pocket, snivel
I'm sorry, ma'am, I--
WHAP! She cuffs him on the side of the head.
I'm displeased with you! Colored boy  like you, falling in with that trash  downstairs!
...Ashamed a yourself! Didn't your  mama raise you right!
Gawain is tramping down the stairs.
I can't do it!
The men are stunned.
Why... this is most... irregular.
She reminds me of my mama. I can't  shoot my mama! You motherfuckers  just draw straws again.
Wait a minute. You've got to accept  your responsibilities, young man.
Fuck you. And your irritated bowel.  I can't shoot that old lady.
Must shoot!
Now look here, it's the easiest thing  in the world. Pretend her head is a  casaba melon, and the gun is a melon- baller, and--
What the fuck you talkin' about,  man? You think this a melon-baller,  you do it, man!
My my, this is most irregular.
Look, with equal rights come equal  responsibilities--
I'm afraid that Mr. Pancake is right,  my dear fellow. We cannot draw straws  again; the exercise loses all  credibility if you show that the  loser can simply beg off doing the  job.
Must shoot!
Gawain shoves the gun toward Pancake.
She just an old colored lady to you --  you do it, man!
Why you sniveling little coward!
What you say, you whiney motherfucker?  I come up your irritated ass with  this -- motherfuckin' gun--
He is waving the gun.
You think you scare me, you mewling  punk! You don't scare me! Bull Connor  and all his dogs didn't scare me!
He shoves Gawain.
...Be a man!
You fuck!
He shoves him back. Pancake shoves:
Be a man!
You ain't no fuckin' man, fuckin' a  sixty-year-old lady in pigtails!
WHY YOU BASTARD PUNK! MOUNTAIN GIRL  IS FIFTY-THREE!
They are shoving each other now, getting into it.
...SHE COULD RIDE YOUR ASS TO JELLY!
He lunges at him with a bear hug and his inertia sends bo men tumbling to the floor, where they roll and wrestle.
Gentlemen, please!
I seen Virginia hams I'd rather stick  my dick in than your old--
BANG! A muffled gunshot. Quiet. The two men have stopped rolling. They stare at each other where they lie, Pancake on top. At length:
...Oh my god...
Horrified, he slowly rises.
...I think he's hit!
The men gather round and look down. Gawain still stares up at the ceiling. Pancake stoops, waves his hand in front of his eyes. No  reaction.
...I'll just check the carotid artery.
He checks the carotid artery.
...That's a negative.
Oh, fuck.
Oh my.
Is he dead, Professor?
Sure he's dead. I checked his carotid  artery.
Well this is most irregular. We will  need a Hefty bag.
Creaking open. The Professor, Lump, and the General peek  out. The living room is empty but a sliver of the kitchen is  visible; its light is on, and we can hear water running. Dorr hisses:
She is in the kitchen. I shall  distract her while you steal out  with the carcass.
Dorr enters breezily; Mrs. Munson is at the sink, filling teapot. Dorr positions himself so that, to talk to him, Mrs. Muns has her back to the living room.
Well, my dear Mrs. Munson, I have  outlined your position to my  colleagues and I now return to you  to return our collective verdict.
Mm-hmm.
Behind her, the General peers around the corner and start catlike advance across the living room.

There was much spirited discussion  and an atmosphere of frank give-and- take. Some of our number were  initially appalled at your proposal  that we simply return the money;  some were more receptive.
I don't care they was receptive or  not!
And that attitude, madam, was a factor  in our discussions. To a man, I must  say, they were devastated at the  prospect of not being able to  contribute to their respective  charities.
The General signals to Lump who now crosses the living ro with a big garbage bag slung over one shoulder in a firem carry.
Well that is a shame.

Indeed. But at the end of the day,  your position prevailed, and the men  have decided that we shall return  the money -- every last cent of it! --  and attend Sunday services, rather  than spend the remainder of our years  wasting away in the Mississippi Men's  Correctional Facility. Though that  was the original preference of some.
Well I'm glad y'all came to see the  light, anyway. I'm gonna have some  tea and go to bed.
The Professor, seeing that the General and Lump have made out the door, is anxious to wind things up:
So the money shall be returned  tomorrow at the opening of the casino  office. Enjoy your tea, madam...

Backing out, he looks to one side. Through the living room window he can see the hearse pull away from the curb. There is another car -- an old Volksw microbus -- slowly tooling the opposite way down the stre Dorr looks back to Mrs. Munson.
...and congratulations on having  recalled to the fold five poor,  confused sheep who had momentarily  strayed.

We are at the middle of the bridge, the tower gargoyle lo blankly down at the doings below. In the misty night Lump and the General are braced over t railing, looking down, each holding one of the feet that  protrude from the Hefty bag cinched around Gawain's ankle A cigarette burns on the General's lower lip. Behind the men we can see the idling hearse. There is the toot of the garbage scow. Lump and the Gener release Gawain's feet. Their POV shows the sack receding and flumping into the  garbage piled onto the scow that slips by below. A flock of scavenger birds, disturbed by the impact, lift off the scow with angry caws.
Dorr skulks at a corner of the living room's picture wind peering out at the street.
The Volkswagon microbus again cruises slowly down the str in the same direction as previously; apparently it has be circling.
The Professor scowls.
The hearse pulls up to the curb.
The Professor clomps down the cellar stairs. Pancake is  loading their digging implements into a satchel.
They back yet?
Dorr is absent:
Yes... yes, they just arrived.
Pancake straightens from the satchel.
Good. I'll go dump these in the  hearse.

He mounts the stairs with a satchel in either hand. We ca hear the front door opening as the other men enter. Dorr, bemused, but apparently moved by a hunch, advances  slowly to the sackbutt case. He slides the catch that lets its spring clasp pop up. He lifts the lid. Mother Jones magazine. Piles of Mother Jones magazines.
What in heaven's name...
He riffles a pile, confirming that it is in fact all maga no money. Lump and the General are clomping down the stairs.
...General!
We are PULLING Clark down the street, a satchel in either hand.
The microbus, parked halfway down the block, ominously id
We are CLOSE on its side-view mirror. Someone leans from driver's seat for a view into the mirror, and in the mirr we see her, pigtails swinging: Mountain Girl.
Clark Pancake, still rather small, approaching up the emp street.
PULLING him again. A smile is beginning to play at the co of his mouth.
No extra share, huh...
The smile abruptly fades. He stops in his tracks for no discernible reason. At leng
...Nnnrnf.
He pants. Behind him, in the deep background, we see the General  bounding into the street and silently toward us.
...Oof!
The moment passes. Pancake shakes his head, as if to clea it, and resumes his walk.
We are nearing the bus.
Mountain Girl sits in the idling bus, waiting. With a thunk and a gentle rock of the bus, we hear its ba doors opening, and Pancake's voice.
Mountain.
Clark.
We hear an oof! of exertion as Pancake hoists each of the two satchels into the back. The oofs are followed by:
...Nnrungh! Aaarmh... Ninnnff...  Offffflleghhll...
IBS, dear?
to show Pancake being garotted by the General.
Nnnnnmmmmfffgh!
